Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Phase II: Center for Electromagnetic Compatibility
Award.AbstractNarration:
The IUCRC for Electromagnetic Compatibility (CEMC) proposes renewal as a two-site I/UCRC, comprising personnel and facilities at the Missouri University of Science and Technology and the University of Houston. CEMC's industry sector requires understanding of noise physics, development of innovative measurement and modeling techniques, and formulation of design methodologies. This includes immunity and electromagnetic interference (EMI), which ensures an electronic system: (1) can function in the presence of external electromagnetic noise; and, (2) its EMI does not impact the functionality of other devices. Signal and power integrity design ensures proper circuit operation at high speeds. Phase II efforts will target development of methods for higher frequencies and smaller geometry scales.

Design for electromagnetic compatibility is critical in electronics. Good electromagnetic compatibility design is essential to successful product development, customer satisfaction and industry competitiveness. Research outcomes from CEMC in Phase I include 31 students graduated from the center and numerous hires of students by industry members. There were over 50 publications and one spin-off company during Phase I with research results incorporated into university courses, and on-site and on-line company short courses. Research outcomes in Phase II will be disseminated through the center website, publications, technical conferences, short courses, IEEE EMC Society committee activities, spin-off companies, and industry application notes. Demonstrations suitable for motivating interest in K-12 students in technical careers are planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the emerging technology trends, such as internet of things (IoT), 5G Wireless, new energy vehicle, autonomous driving, the need for electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) research and education grows rapidly.  Not only new challenges occur due to higher data rates, greater design density, and lower power, but also new scopes are required to address new issues.  EMC becomes truly essential to enable and support technology revolutions and development. The NSF IUCRC Center for Electromagnetic Compatibility (CEMC) in Phase II continues to be very successful, with its total membership fee in the upper tier of the IUCRC program.  Evaluations of center members show high satisfaction with center operations and research outcomes. The center was successfully expanded in Phase II with University of Hawaii-Manoa joined as the third site. The shared challenge projects based on the collaborative research model have been expanded to be a significant portion of the Center research. 

Technically, the CEMC has achieved significant outcomes in all the proposed focus areas in Phase II, at the fronts of developing specialized engineering tools, developing innovative measurement and modeling methodologies, and developing physical understanding. For example, the sparse Emission Source Microscopy (ESM) scanner with super resolution capabilities developed in the center provides a method for quick and robust localization of the EMI sources along with an estimate of the radiated power of each source. This allows EMC engineers to easily locate EMI sources with higher accuracy and lowers the risk of EMI compliance problems late in design cycles. The new type of de-embedding methodology developed for measuring PCB structures, together with its associated engineering tool, is another example. This developed new methodology fits well with "real-world" engineering practice, significantly simplifies the calibration pattern designs and measurement procedures, and reduces measurement time. It has been widely adopted by member companies.  

In aspect of center operation, in phase II, the CEMC has increased the allocation of the membership funds for shared challenge projects from 5% to 20%.  Due to the nature of our technical field being more engineering oriented, the regular research projects are allowed to have specific needs from sponsoring member companies incorporated, even though the overall objectives and research plans in an area are reviewed and determined by the IAB.  Shared challenge projects were designed to embrace the collaborative research model among our members.  The success of the shared challenge projects has demonstrated sufficient benefits to our members, and the current rate of 20% represents that a significant portion of the total research activities conducted in the CEMC is now based on the collaborative research model. We believe this is a big milestone that the CEMC has achieved in center operation.

The research innovations from the CEMC have resulted in significant advancements in high-speed digital design, wireless, data communication, medical devices, benefiting a significant portion of society. Also, the unique training and education received by the undergraduate and graduate students, as well as the post-doctoral fellows, have led to highly-experienced engineers and research professionals in an important area critical to the nation’s high tech industry. The CEMC is a resource for the EMC community, facilitating research collaborations, disseminating results, and transferring knowledge. It has enhanced the research experiences for the faculty members directly involved in the center, and facilitated collaborations between the center faculty and the other faculty members in the ECE department and on campus. Outcomes of academic research have been effectively disseminated to industry through the established mechanisms in the center such as the IAB meetings, engineering tools, spin-off start-ups, product commercialization, publications, application notes, and short courses.
